ygData.msgSnippet: I have an application built around NEAT, that runs well and optimises as planned, but it never achieves its target because I always get an allocation

Subject: Memory usage and the generations stack in NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=175530192; y=ZIgO7pwPhgRl22XiBtXaKRIVjlyf_p1UfLcNfuk0x1bexvXA
X-Yahoo-Profile: rmarsdena

I have an application built around NEAT, that runs well and optimises as 
planned, but it never achieves its target because I always get an 
allocation exception.

The generated network isn't large. It has 7 inputs and 1 output and 
usually around 3 or 4 hidden nodes, but the program still runs out of 
memory on 32bit Windows, with 4GB of RAM. Task Manager shows the slow 
but inexorable increase in memory size. The limit is usually hit around 
10,000 generations. It sounds a lot but tests on random Out-of-Sample 
data, whenever there is an improvement in performance would suggest that 
we haven't yet reached over-fitting.

So... is there anything I can do to avoid the need to keep the complete 
generation history, which seems to be the root of the problem.

This is a different problem to that I cited in my message of 13-Jan-2011.

-- 
Rob Marsden
Gistix (Northern) Limited
